From CNN (emphases mine):
Lesbians' brains react differently to sex hormones than those of heterosexual women.
 
 An earlier study of gay men also showed their brain response was different from straight men -- an even stronger difference than has now been found in lesbians.
 
 Lesbians' brains reacted somewhat, though not completely, like those of heterosexual men, a team of Swedish researchers said in Tuesday's edition of Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
 
 A year ago, the same group reported findings for gay men that showed their brain response to hormones was similar to that of heterosexual women.
 
 In both cases the findings add weight to the idea that homosexuality has a physical basis and is not learned behavior.
 
 "It shows sexual orientation may very well have a different basis between men and women ... this is not just a mirror image situation," said Sandra Witelson, an expert on brain anatomy and sexual orientation at the Michael G. DeGroote School of Medicine at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario.
 
 "The important thing is to be open to the likely situation that there are biological factors that contribute to sexual orientation," added Witelson, who was not part of the research team.
 
 The research team led by Ivanka Savic at the Stockholm Brain Institute had volunteers sniff chemicals derived from male and female sex hormones. These chemicals are thought to be pheromones -- molecules known to trigger responses such as defense and sex in many animals.
 
 Whether humans respond to pheromones has been debated, although in 2000 American researchers reported finding a gene that they believe directs a human pheromone receptor in the nose.
 
 The same team reported last year on a comparison of the response of male homosexuals to heterosexual men and women. They found that the brains of gay men reacted more like those of women than of straight men.
 The new study shows a similar, but weaker, relationship between the response of lesbians and straight men.
 
 Heterosexual women found the male and female pheromones about equally pleasant, while straight men and lesbians liked the female pheromone more than the male one. Men and lesbians also found the male hormone more irritating than the female one, while straight women were more likely to be irritated by the female hormone than the male one.
 
 All three groups rated the male hormone more familiar than the female one. Straight women found both hormones about equal in intensity, while lesbians and straight men found the male hormone more intense than the female one.
 
 The brains of all three groups were scanned when sniffing male and female hormones and a set of four ordinary odors. Ordinary odors were processed in the brain circuits associated with smell in all the volunteers.
 
 In heterosexual males the male hormone was processed in the scent area but the female hormone was processed in the hypothalamus, which is related to sexual stimulation. In straight women the sexual area of the brain responded to the male hormone while the female hormone was perceived by the scent area.
 
 In lesbians, both male and female hormones were processed the same, in the basic odor processing circuits, Savic and her team reported.
 
 Each of the three groups of subjects included 12 healthy, unmedicated, right-handed and HIV-negative individuals.
 
 The research was funded by the Swedish Medical Research Council, Karolinska Institute and the Wallenberg Foundation.
 http://www.cnn.com/2006/HEALTH/05/08/lesbian.brains.ap/index.html

Well, he would be right that it doesn't prove that it's genetic, but he would be very wrong to say that therefore it is a choice.

Yes, I do. But I don't think that "homosexuality is a choice," however much I disagree (at least in the purest form of the meaning of "choice"), is yet quite on the level of "the earth is flat" or "the sun rotates around the earth."

 
 1) Any discussion on "homosexuality is a choice" obviously conjures up a question of the parallel.
 Is heterosexuality a choice?
 I see no rationality behind any pretense that homosexuality is a choice, while heterosexuality is not.
 2) Science has unilaterally observed that homosexuality IS NOT a choice. I have yet to see ANY reason for ANYBODY to believe that homosexuality is a choice, beyond convenience of stereo-types and their personal beliefs...
 It may not be "quite on the level" of the other two examples, but I think the comparison is apt and not unreasonable.
 3) The whole "choice" thing gets annoying (or perhaps boring) in multiple ways. One of which is the quibbling over what constitutes "homosexuality".
 I have seen some people define homosexuality EXCLUSIVELY by sexual action, which I find unreasonable and not in keeping with the average definition.
 4) The whole "choice" thing gets annoying (or perhaps boring) in another way. A pretense of the existence of an "unconscious choice" (with regards to claiming that homosexuals "unconsciously choose" to be homosexuals). What the heck would an "unconscious choice" be anyways?
 Perhaps your "purest form of choice" comments were directly or indirectly commenting on that?

And I would agree 100% with your assessment.
 I believe the proof of genetic components lies elsewhere.
 
 And the main point of my comment was to point out the second item you noted, which I feel is a rather egregious logical flaw in different ways...

 I apologize, what was it that you thought was a logical flaw?

I apologize, what was it that you thought was a logical flaw?

 1) I don't understand why you apologize, but that's not important...
 2) Suppose John sees two cups. One labelled "choice". Another labelled "genetics".
 He says there is a quarter under one of those cups, and demands that others prove that it is under the cup labelled "genetics", otherwise we must assume it is under the cup called "choice".
 
 Fallacies:
 a) There are MORE than just two cups on the table. The "quarter" could be under a variety of cups...
 b) Flipping the argument, we could demand John prove the quarter is under "choice", otherwise we must assume it is under "genetics". That argument is just as rationale.
 c) Science has pretty definitively demonstrated that the quarter IS NOT under the "choice" cup. As such, John is ignoring a crucial bit of info in his assessment.
 d) The statement assumes that the "genetics" cup can be overturned to definitively prove the presence, or absence, of the quarter in the first place. Genetics is much more complicated, ESPECIALLY on the behavioral genetics issue, than just pointing to a definitive quarter existing under a cup. EVIDENCE exists demonstrating that the quarter, or at least a portion of a quarter, is under that cup. But the fact that we cannot physically pick up that quarter and parade it around IS NOT proof that the quarter has to be under the choice cup...
 
 I think "d" may be tying together previous points, but you get the picture...

I simply meant that I think you're looking for raging religiousity to confront because that is easy to dismiss. 
 I'm really not, trust me. I would LOVE to see a rational argument, i.e., one based on science and logic, that addresses this issue. I just didn't see any attempt at such in your post, just the statement that you find the "born-that-way-or-not" argument a bore, which I didn't find added anything to the discussion. (I usually appreciate and enjoy your posts, as a rule.) I find a lot of arguments on lots of threads boring, but no one is holding a gun to my head forcing me to read them, and I'm not going to log onto each of them just to go "yawn." I realize that lots of other people find them interesting and cogent, and who am I to go out of my way to sneer at them for it? 
 
 I personally think this biological element stuff highly relevant--not because it should be (it shouldn't), but because it directly attacks the cornerstone of the It's A Sin Group's contention--that homosexuals are really just heterosexuals who deliberately choose to do disgusting things (for motives never defined), rather than people who are simply following their natural, hard-wired attractions the same as they do. And every new rock added to the growing mountain of facts showing that the latter is, indeed, the case just makes head-in-the-sand irrationalists like unkerpaulie look more and more ludicrous.

1) I don't understand why you apologize, but that's not important...

 I just menat I guess I didn't address what you were looking for.
 
2) Suppose John sees two cups. One labelled "choice". Another labelled "genetics".
 He says there is a quarter under one of those cups, and demands that others prove that it is under the cup labelled "genetics", otherwise we must assume it is under the cup called "choice".
 
 Fallacies:
 a) There are MORE than just two cups on the table. The "quarter" could be under a variety of cups...

b) Flipping the argument, we could demand John prove the quarter is under "choice", otherwise we must assume it is under "genetics". That argument is just as rationale.

 Or maybe it would be better to say it's just as "irrational" emoticon_xhoho 
 
c) Science has pretty definitively demonstrated that the quarter IS NOT under the "choice" cup. As such, John is ignoring a crucial bit of info in his assessment.

 Science has shown that there is some evidence of homosexuality in the brain. However, it's just as much of a fallacy to say that this "definitively demonstrates" that it is not "choice" as the the fallacy you mentioned above.
 
d) The statement assumes that the "genetics" cup can be overturned to definitively prove the presence, or absence, of the quarter in the first place. Genetics is much more complicated, ESPECIALLY on the behavioral genetics issue, than just pointing to a definitive quarter existing under a cup. EVIDENCE exists demonstrating that the quarter, or at least a portion of a quarter, is under that cup. But the fact that we cannot physically pick up that quarter and parade it around IS NOT proof that the quarter has to be under the choice cup...
 
 I think "d" may be tying together previous points, but you get the picture...

 You're right. It's not proof that the quarter is under the choice cup. But as I stated before, having some evidence of homosexuality in the brain does not prove it is genetic either.

And the main point of my comment was to point out the second item you noted, which I feel is a rather egregious logical flaw in different ways...
 
 
 
 
 1) Any discussion on "homosexuality is a choice" obviously conjures up a question of the parallel.
 Is heterosexuality a choice?
 I see no rationality behind any pretense that homosexuality is a choice, while heterosexuality is not.

 Fair enough.
 
3) The whole "choice" thing gets annoying (or perhaps boring) in multiple ways. One of which is the quibbling over what constitutes "homosexuality".
 I have seen some people define homosexuality EXCLUSIVELY by sexual action, which I find unreasonable and not in keeping with the average definition.

 Just so you know, this isn't my main concern here. I too think that defining it exclusively by sexual activity is innaccurate.
 
4) The whole "choice" thing gets annoying (or perhaps boring) in another way. A pretense of the existence of an "unconscious choice" (with regards to claiming that homosexuals "unconsciously choose" to be homosexuals). What the heck would an "unconscious choice" be anyways?
 Perhaps your "purest form of choice" comments were directly or indirectly commenting on that?

 I believe they were. I know that there is evidence of homosexuality in the brain as I mentioned in my last post. And I believe that there may be a genetic basis to homosexuality, or a genetic basis for a dispostion to homsexuality in some people. But I don't think everyone is the same. It is more complex than genetics.

I personally think this biological element stuff highly relevant--not because it should be (it shouldn't), but because it directly attacks the cornerstone of the It's A Sin Group's contention--that homosexuals are really just heterosexuals who deliberately choose to do disgusting things (for motives never defined), rather than people who are simply following their natural, hard-wired attractions the same as they do. And every new rock added to the growing mountain of facts showing that the latter is, indeed, the case just makes head-in-the-sand irrationalists like unkerpaulie look more and more ludicrous.

 
 I agree.
 Personally, I wouldn't care if was completely a choice, because I am an adult and same-sex behavior harms no one. 
 
 So I, too, think the search for a biological element is extremely important (beyond my fascination with the pure science) precisely because of your point. And that is exactly why the anti-gay religious right are so very threatened by this scientific information. It puts a complete hole in their argument and they then have no non-religious argument for opposing gay rights. As with evolution, they make accusations of the motives of scientists, who merely are searching for knowledge. They cannot refute the science so they either attack the scientist or put forth (a la unker, JP, et al.) arguments that are not scientifically sound.

I'm really not, trust me. I would LOVE to see a rational argument, i.e., one based on science and logic, that addresses this issue. I just didn't see any attempt at such in your post, just the statement that you find the "born-that-way-or-not" argument a bore, which I didn't find added anything to the discussion. I realize that lots of other people find them interesting and cogent, and who am I to go out of my way to sneer at them for it?

And every new rock added to the growing mountain of facts showing that the latter is, indeed, the case just makes head-in-the-sand irrationalists like unkerpaulie look more and more ludicrous.

 Ok, I believe that you aren't trying to do that now. I just see it so often and it really bothers me.
 You're right, even though I hinted at my thoughts about this, I didn't directly say anything that added to the discussion. Sorry 'bout that.
 What I really meant by saying that I find this boring, was that I don't think it is the most important issue. However, I do understand where you are coming from and why it can be a potentially very important argument if it is really the case. But another part of me says that if you could prove today beyond a reasonable doubt that homosexuality was 100% genetic, the fundamentalist that are arguing against it now would still be arguing against it. We see that so clearly when it comes to things like evolution. On the other hand, it probably would convince a lot of fence sitters, so it is important. I guess what I should have said was I don't think this is the most important issue in terms of winning support. Nonetheless, I still find it fascinating and would like to continue discussing it.

 Adding on a comment about how contradictory it is for people to claim that homosexuality is both a "choice", and a "mental illness". (Or "sin" and "mental illness").
 
 Sin/choice are choices.
 People don't choose to have a "mental illness". Schizophrenics don't "choose" to be mentally ill. Manic depressives don't "choose" to have their problems.
 
 The two categories are contradictory...

Or maybe it would be better to say it's just as "irrational" emoticon_xhoho 

 emoticon_xgood 
 
 
 
Science has shown that there is some evidence of homosexuality in the brain. However, it's just as much of a fallacy to say that this "definitively demonstrates" that it is not "choice" as the the fallacy you mentioned above.

 "DEFINITIVELY demonstrates"? I would agree, based on the adverb used.
 But it sure does point towards something, even if it isn't definitive.
 
 
 
You're right. It's not proof that the quarter is under the choice cup. But as I stated before, having some evidence of homosexuality in the brain does not prove it is genetic either.

 But by the same token, don't you think it provides proof that the quarter is not under the choice cup?
 I don't think individuals can just "choose" their brain chemistry.
 (Grossly over-simplifying statement, but you get the gist...)
 
 
 
I believe they were. I know that there is evidence of homosexuality in the brain as I mentioned in my last post. And I believe that there may be a genetic basis to homosexuality, or a genetic basis for a dispostion to homsexuality in some people. But I don't think everyone is the same. It is more complex than genetics.

 And I often try to phrase my discussion as explicitly stating a genetic COMPONENT because of that complexity.
 I believe the current scientific consensus is that sexual orientation is based on BOTH nature AND nurture. But how that all comes together is not really understood.
 
 I think it's fair to say that science has proven that genetic component of sexual orientation is somewhere between 0% and 100%, with the 0% and 100% ends being excluded as possibilities...

"DEFINITIVELY demonstrates"? I would agree, based on the adverb used. But it sure does point towards something, even if it isn't definitive.

 I was just using your language.
 
But by the same token, don't you think it provides proof that the quarter is not under the choice cup?

 Not necessarily. First of all there is this evidence in some people. Secondly, the brain is a very complex thing. Some elements of the brain are purely genetic, some are changes that have occurred based on events and actions in the persons life. So, evidence for homosexuality in the brain only shows that some element of it is now in the brain and effecting behavior. It does not say how this became a part of the brain.
 
And I often try to phrase my discussion as explicitly stating a genetic COMPONENT because of that complexity.
 I believe the current scientific consensus is that sexual orientation is based on BOTH nature AND nurture. But how that all comes together is not really understood.
 
 I think it's fair to say that science has proven that genetic component of sexual orientation is somewhere between 0% and 100%, with the 0% and 100% ends being excluded as possibilities...

 Based on what I said above, I don't know that science has necessarily proven this. It doesn't mean that it won't, but I don't know thatthis evidence proves it. However, I do believe that there are elements of nature and nurture involved, to varying degrees, depending on the person.

Ok, I believe that you aren't trying to do that now. I just see it so often and it really bothers me.
 You're right, even though I hinted at my thoughts about this, I didn't directly say anything that added to the discussion. Sorry 'bout that.
 What I really meant by saying that I find this boring, was that I don't think it is the most important issue. However, I do understand where you are coming from and why it can be a potentially very important argument if it is really the case. But another part of me says that if you could prove today beyond a reasonable doubt that homosexuality was 100% genetic, the fundamentalist that are arguing against it now would still be arguing against it. We see that so clearly when it comes to things like evolution. On the other hand, it probably would convince a lot of fence sitters, so it is important. I guess what I should have said was I don't think this is the most important issue in terms of winning support. Nonetheless, I still find it fascinating and would like to continue discussing it.
 
 emoticon_xgood 
 
 Incidentally, re: "proof"... science never "definitively proves" ANYTHING. And we're talking math to physics to chemistry to biology to cosmology to... well, you name it. The very NATURE of scientific investigation (unlike religion, which claims absolute certainty) is based on falsifiability, and everything we know is subject to constant re-examination and testing. All we can ever do is come as close as we can to the "truth" of something--we never know it absolutely. It's like peeling an onion with no center... you just keep peeling.
 
 The fact that you never reach the center, however, in no way invalidates the existence of the onion. Much less proves that it must be a radish instead.

emoticon_xgood

 The fact that you never reach the center, however, in no way invalidates the existence of the onion. Much less proves that it must be a radish instead.

 I understand that. My point was, even if it was possible and you did it, you're never going to convince fundamentalists. In terms of the evidence presented here and other similar evidence, like I said in a previous post, I do not believe it is solid evidence for a genetic basis. I'm not saying it's not out there and I'm not saying it is, I'm simply saying that I don't believe this is it.
